name: NewYorker
text: Jill Lepore writes about how a data-analytics firm helped swing the 1960 election for J. F. K., using the “secret weapon” that began modern American politics. https://t.co/Ak4T1PrHHI

name: NewYorker
text: Olivia de Havilland, who died on Sunday, at 104, spent a lifetime crusading for what she felt she deserved. https://t.co/AP012zUF6p

name: NewYorker
text: From “utepils” (Norwegian, “beer that is enjoyed outside, particularly on the first hot day of the year”) to “mbuki-mvuki” (Bantu, “to shed clothes to dance uninhibited”), the Positive Lexicography Project gathers untranslatable words describing happiness. https://t.co/rgEovRYPxK

name: NewYorker
text: New discoveries about the human mind show the limitations of reason. https://t.co/9I5AmPb3Uk

name: NewYorker
text: "Mercifully, I had no idea it was going to be 40 years," John Williams said, about scoring the "Star Wars" saga. "I was not a youngster when I started, and I feel, in retrospect, enormously fortunate to have had the energy to be able to finish it.” https://t.co/zjdn0s27Dm

name: NewYorker
text: “I wonder if my dead mother still thinks of me.” A poem by @theferocity. https://t.co/cLigaMD5GQ

name: NewYorker
text: The lynching of a man named Robert Edwards, in 1912, inaugurated a decades-long reign of terror in Forsyth County, Georgia. In “Blood at the Root,” Patrick Phillips delves into his home town’s violent history—and asks what we can do today. https://t.co/DOrSpQqpJS

name: NewYorker
text:
If we assume that there is, to a certain degree, a fixed amount of work necessary for society to function, how can we at once be more productive and have more workers, and yet still be working more hours?
https://t.co/zu3IE5zWa8

text:
Mourning the place of the landline in fiction, a device which has long been a source of surprise, suspense, and uncertainty.
https://t.co/q4gocQZ9z0

name: NewYorker
text: “Obviously, Black lives matter within the capitalism of the N.F.L.,” Michael Bennett said. But what if players demanded more Black coaches, and more diversity in ownership? https://t.co/SSuZHQCyBb

name: NewYorker
text: "My mom has been a server at Red Lobster since Ronald Reagan served as President," Zach Zimmerman writes. The location where she works is near Myrtle Beach, in South Carolina, where coronavirus cases skyrocketed after an aggressive reopening. https://t.co/gBKrObZse4

name: NewYorker
text: On a new episode of our podcast, @JaneMayerNYer discusses how Ronald Cameron, the owner of one of the largest poultry producers, is leveraging the coronavirus crisis to strip workers of their protections. Listen here. https://t.co/ImIwX7f4wC

name: NewYorker
text: For many health-care workers, initial concerns about the rationing of P.P.E. have been replaced with the weighty recognition that the fight against COVID-19 is not a momentary disruption but a new way of life. https://t.co/QG4k4eFtRc

name: NewYorker
text: Susan Neiman, a philosopher who studies Germany’s confrontation with its Nazi past, discusses how the U.S. can reckon with its racist history. https://t.co/tcsTkboSUL

name: NewYorker
text: An American couple’s baby was scheduled to be born to a surrogate on April 24th, in Ukraine. By March, COVID-19 was making headlines, and soon what had begun as a minor tragedy—missing their daughter’s birth—started to seem like an emergency. https://t.co/K7M3euFKpt

name: NewYorker
text: At Ras Plant Based, flaky sambusas, stuffed with either lentils or chopped cabbage, onion, and bell pepper, come two per order. "I knew that I should have added at least a half-dozen to my takeout cart," @hannahgoldfield writes. https://t.co/1r1fPkapk4

name: NewYorker
text: .@rachsyme reflects on the legacy of Olivia de Havilland, who once told her that drinking champagne every day was the secret to eternal youth. https://t.co/O4URDx45lk
